newsitem.title: USA: U.S tobacco industry talks trigger debt tightening.
newsitem.headline: U.S tobacco industry talks trigger debt tightening.

text.p: Spreads on tobacco bonds tightened on Wednesday after news hit the Street that tobacco executives were in negotiations with state attorneys general on a possible settlement of litigation against the industry.
"Tobacco debt was tighter today, specifically, the longer paper," said one high-grade trader.
Among 10-year sector paper, RJR Nabisco debt due 2005 was tighter by five to ten basis points at a 205 bid, 200 offer.
Philip Morris' 7.20 percent paper due 2007 was quoted tighter by about three basis points at an 85 bid, 80 offer, traders said.
Pressure had been steadily building on the tobacco industry to seek a resolution to mounting lawsuits and other legal developments against it.
Last month, Liggett Group, owned by Brooke Groupe Ltd, reached a historic settlement with attorneys general, becoming the first tobacco firm to admit that nicotine is addictive.
It also agreed to turn over internal documents that could prove damaging to the entire industry.
Meanwhile, shorter-dated tobacco paper was seen a touch tighter to unchanged, traders said.
Phillip Morris' 7-1/2s of 2002 were quoted 68 basis points bid, 63 offer. RJR's 8-5/8's of 2002 were trading at a 170 basis point bid, while the 7.625's of 2003 were bid at 195.
